reviewText:
PROS: The game's HD textures look nice, and the speed stages are beautiful when it's just about running through the level. The Chao garden is also a decent distraction.

CONS: Just like Sonic Adventure, this game has aged like milk. The Tails/Eggman levels are slow and a bit unresponsive at times, and the Knux/Rouge levels are a scavenger hunt. The extra missions can be very tedious at times, and annoying to do. The camera whips around like a drunkard, often times away from where you have to go. The hit detection's a bit wonky in the speed stages as well. The worst though, is without the Battle Addon, the game has no audio, about 75% of sounds missing, and lags horribly.

ACHIEVEMENTS: Have fun grinding all of the levels out for A's.

FINAL: I can't in full consciousness recommend this game. It's a poor HD port of a poor game, so steer clear if you can.

I just finished Sonic Adventure 2, and I gotta say; Very few games are incredible. And this is one of those few. The plot is exceptional with a couple show-stopping plot twists at the end (I won't spoil them, you'll have to play it for yourself :)), the controls are great, and the level design is AMAZING. The bosses are amazing (some can be annoying, though), and it has plenty of replay value with the Chao Garden, and you should try to A-rank every stage (which of course I can't do XD) My only problem with this game might be with the grind rails in the final rush stage. But aside from that, this game should NOT be missed. It beats out the first game in the series by far.


Overall, I give this game a 10/10.

reviewText:
If your looking for a really unique action-adventure game with a blending of different types of gameplay styles well look no further. Sonic Adventure 2 expands upon the original Sonic Adventure, adding bigger levels (although sadly no more open world), more upgrades to find, more characters to play with, a tamogachi inspired Chao raising garden, Kart races, and even a 2 player racing and battle mode if your inclined to take part in.

If all of this sounds too good to be true, well you should be happy to know that won't be disappointed as long as your expecting a game that by all accounts isn't perfect, but its just so unique and has that Sega Dreamcast era charm and personality that it might as well be and you definitely be hard pressed to find similar games to it even to this day.

Now lets get down to all this varied gameplay I was talking about earlier, in this game there are specifically 3 different types of gameplay styles which include Sonic/Shadow which their levels are all about going fast, bouncing on enemies, and is generally the type of gameplay you would expect from a Sonic game. You then have Knuckles/Rogue levels where they have to have find Chaos Emeralds shards or keys in a level by listening to a radar to see if they are close and then either straight out picking it up or digging in the ground for it or even just killing an enemy. Last, but not least is the Tails/Robotnik levels which are essentially updated Gamma levels from Sonic Adventure 1 where you will go through a level locking on and shooting lots of enemies while trying to get to the end. It's also worth mentioning that going through story mode you will also sometimes come across the usual boss fights and even the occassional racing mini-game to add even more to the mix.

Now to the part where about half of you will love and the other will hate and thats the Chao Garden. You see, throughout each level in the game, you pick up these colored objects and even small animals that you can take back to the garden and feed to your chao to make it level up in a certain attribute which you can take to compete in races or even battle it out karate style! They also evolve and change depending on how you grow them and there are some secrets even to be had with them. The part however that some people do not like with this big part of the game is that it is essential to raise a chao to have high stats and do all the races/battles so that you can get 100% completion which unlocks a special level and raising chao is not a fast endeavor.

All in all, the game itself is great. The port however...has a few kinks to work out with getting it to work with Fullscreen mode now with a new patch, but is semi-easily fixed, so if you can get it working then you should have a great time with the game and this game will take you quite a while as well if you try to get all the Emblems and A-Ranks as well, so there's that, but if you just try and finish the story mode by itself with some or little chao raising then your looking at a solid 10 hour game.

reviewText: Sonic Adventure 2 has finally made its way to PC here on STEAM.\nIf you've played Sonic Adventure you might want to know that in terms on in between levels, this game is vastly different as this time around you choose between two sides of the main story instead of 6 characters with each of their own story (all of them still being connected though). In this game however, the two sides follow one main story, just from different perspectives. There is the Hero side and the Dark side, each side has 3 playable characters with different game types of their own. The game types are Adventure Stages (Sonic/Shadow), Action Shooter stages (Tails/Eggman) and Treasure Hunting stages (Knuckles/Rouge). Though this game is, in my personal opinion, a very enjoyable game, it shows some aging with minor bugs/glitches throwing you through platforms and between the tiniest gaps, but that happens rarely. If you haven't got any ver. of this game yet (Dreamcast or Gamecube), I would highly recommend getting this as it is available here on Steam at a verry reasonable price. If you purchase the SA2 Battle DLC you will get additional game modes for the Multi Player section AND a new mini game in Chao Garden.

reviewText:
The base game is good and in the moment you'll find yourself caught up in the story. There is a very meaty challenege for anyone trying to 100% the game. I did it on PS3 and really enjoyed it.

Gameplay can be broken down into 4 parts:

Speed: You're Sonic/Shadow you run through levels. The best part of the game.

Shooting: Tails/Eggman are in mechs and you have a lock on lazer cannon the idea of each stage being how many enemies you can target at once before losing the lock, pretty neat once you get into it.

Treasure Hunting: Knuckles/Rouge fly around contained levels looking for 3 of something. You can climb, glide, dig, it's fun to just run around as them really.

There's also a few mods out that are pretty great and I highly recommend hitting up Sonic Retro for them.

Now for a controversial opinion: Chao Garden sucks.
A lot of people will try to tell you the chao portion is something special. It was easily the poorest portion of the game by far. It's tedious, it's annoying, it's not deep or interesting it's a time waster through and through.

Essentially all the enemies in the game drop animals or energy cores that you can give to the chao leveling them up so they can better race or fight. The racing and fighting however are slow paced affairs you have no impact on other than cheering making the whole affair a massive time waster.

In short: Mechanically solid game with an excellent aesthetic, it has a tacked on time waster you need to 100% the game but you can ignore it really.

reviewText:
TL;DR:  It's a bit rough around the edges, but Sonic Adventure 2's a pretty fun 3D action platformer and solid entry in the Sonic series.

I'll start this by saying I bought as a part of the Sonic Everywhere bundle on Amazon a while back for $15 on sale.  Steam has the same bundle for $30 normal price.

Sonic Adventure 2: Battle.  Oh man, I remember this from the Gamecube.  It was my first actual 3D Sonic, since I entirely skipped the Saturn and Dreamcast.  I never thought I'd see it on PC, honestly.  This is a port of a port, but that's not all that bad.  I'll try not to mention anything related to the 2P mode or the Battle DLC additions.

The game is split into three sections told by two separate stories between Hero and Dark.  Sonic and Shadow are the typical high-speed platforming/rail-grinding/Homing Attacking gameplay where you get to the goal ring.  Tails and Dr. Eggman travel through levels in bipedal mechs and blow things up with some platforming elements.  Knuckles and Rouge climb, glide, and dig through large levels to find three Master Emerald shards or keys or so on.  The stories happen at the same time but are told by different sides, and by beating both Hero and Dark stories, Last Story is unlocked and through that the true ending to the game is revealed.

Gameplay is different from Sonic Adventure in that instead of merely choosing one character and using only that character until their respective ending, you pick between good and evil and you go through that side's stages alternating between Sonic, Tails, and Knuckles for Hero and Shadow, Eggman, and Rouge for Dark.  There are no Adventure Fields to traverse between levels, so the flow goes between Action Stages and story events with some boss battles sprinkled in.  Every character fights his or her opposing-side match one or more times in a boss fight, though there are some third-party battles too.

What I Liked
There is a good bit of content though you don't need to see it all to beat the game.  Every stage has five missions, though you only beat the first mission as you go through the story mode.  The other four missions are optional challenges, and every mission gives you a rank based on score.  Emblems are also awarded for clearing missions and other tasks, and getting all of them is a pretty big undertaking since there are 180 of them.  Getting all A-ranks in every mission is something a challenge-seeker would enjoy.  There is a leaderboard feature so you can compare scores between everyone or just friends.

The music is catchy.  Some of the songs during the stages have lyrics which doesn't really detract from the experience.  I hope you like rock and some hip-hop, though.  All of Knuckles' stages have lyrics present, a couple of the Sonic and Shadow stages have them, all of Rogue's stages have female singers present.  All six characters have theme songs too which pop up during the story, and if you want to listen to those or any other song in full, there's a sound test in the options, so that's nice.

Chao Garden.  Chao are cute little creatures found in Chao World separate to the story that you are tasked with hatching and raising, albeit optionally unless you want to get all of the game's emblems.  While only able to crawl around like an infant at first, by feeding them Chaos Drives and small animals found in the stages, they will grow and take on features of the animals.  Raised Chao can be entered in races, though you have no direct control over their performance outside of a little boost to speed.  There is some incentive to keep going back to the stages to get items to raise the little creatures and it is kinda nice to take care of them and watch them grow and change...and stop drowning in the little pond.

What I Didn't Like
There is a lack of polish with this port, and at times they seemed to fix a couple of things but leave some others strangely untouched.  For example, the wow
date: he's fast hey it's not his speed he's using the Chaos Emerald to warp" line during the story bit when Sonic first meets Shadow IS given a gap
recommended: but the "you're not even good enough--"  "I'll make you eat those words!" before Sonic and Shadow's first fight is not.  The mouths move with the Japanese audio and not with the English which results in some cutting off at times
hoursPlayed: or people talking after their mouths stopped moving.  Rouge's eyes actually went through her eyelids a few times
voteText: and the perspective of one scene put both of Amy's eyes on the same side of her face.  I didn't really have much problem during the gameplay
helpfulPercent: barring a couple of instances where hitting a boost pad the wrong way resulted in an unavoidable death.\n\nI did not like the treasure hunting stages.  Even Tails and Eggman's sections I enjoyed even if they're not very Sonicy.  I dunno
votesHelpful: I guess a big problem I have is that the radar only tracks the first item in a list.  You can be standing right next to a shard or something and the radar won't tell you unless it's the first in a line.  I understand why it's set up that way
votesTotal: but that's a problem I have with the core game as opposed to this port.  The stages are wide open and there are hint monitors
votesFunny: but they boil down to just hide-and-seek at best and pixel hunting at worst.  There are some interesting features like dodging the invincible enemy in Egg Quarters or adjusting the water level in Aquatic Mine
commentsCount: but at this point I'm just ranting.\n\nAnd speaking of ranting
column16:
Mad Space!  Just pretend I said "treasure hunting but worse" here.

Closing
So in closing...it's an old game.  The graphics are visibly dated
column17: the camera is a bit of a chore to fight against
column18: and the story can be kinda hit-or-miss.  But I had fun with it
column19: even for it not being new to me anymore.  I put in just 15 hours to clear the game this time around
column20: and that was with giving plenty of time to Chao Garden.  Besides

Battle DLC

reviewText:
TL;DR:  It's a bit rough around the edges, but Sonic Adventure 2's a pretty fun 3D action platformer and solid entry in the Sonic series.

I'll start this by saying I bought as a part of the Sonic Everywhere bundle on Amazon a while back for $15 on sale.  Steam has the same bundle for $30 normal price.

Sonic Adventure 2: Battle.  Oh man, I remember this from the Gamecube.  It was my first actual 3D Sonic, since I entirely skipped the Saturn and Dreamcast.  I never thought I'd see it on PC, honestly.  This is a port of a port, but that's not all that bad.  I'll try not to mention anything related to the 2P mode or the Battle DLC additions.

The game is split into three sections told by two separate stories between Hero and Dark.  Sonic and Shadow are the typical high-speed platforming/rail-grinding/Homing Attacking gameplay where you get to the goal ring.  Tails and Dr. Eggman travel through levels in bipedal mechs and blow things up with some platforming elements.  Knuckles and Rouge climb, glide, and dig through large levels to find three Master Emerald shards or keys or so on.  The stories happen at the same time but are told by different sides, and by beating both Hero and Dark stories, Last Story is unlocked and through that the true ending to the game is revealed.

Gameplay is different from Sonic Adventure in that instead of merely choosing one character and using only that character until their respective ending, you pick between good and evil and you go through that side's stages alternating between Sonic, Tails, and Knuckles for Hero and Shadow, Eggman, and Rouge for Dark.  There are no Adventure Fields to traverse between levels, so the flow goes between Action Stages and story events with some boss battles sprinkled in.  Every character fights his or her opposing-side match one or more times in a boss fight, though there are some third-party battles too.

What I Liked
There is a good bit of content though you don't need to see it all to beat the game.  Every stage has five missions, though you only beat the first mission as you go through the story mode.  The other four missions are optional challenges, and every mission gives you a rank based on score.  Emblems are also awarded for clearing missions and other tasks, and getting all of them is a pretty big undertaking since there are 180 of them.  Getting all A-ranks in every mission is something a challenge-seeker would enjoy.  There is a leaderboard feature so you can compare scores between everyone or just friends.

The music is catchy.  Some of the songs during the stages have lyrics which doesn't really detract from the experience.  I hope you like rock and some hip-hop, though.  All of Knuckles' stages have lyrics present, a couple of the Sonic and Shadow stages have them, all of Rogue's stages have female singers present.  All six characters have theme songs too which pop up during the story, and if you want to listen to those or any other song in full, there's a sound test in the options, so that's nice.

Chao Garden.  Chao are cute little creatures found in Chao World separate to the story that you are tasked with hatching and raising, albeit optionally unless you want to get all of the game's emblems.  While only able to crawl around like an infant at first, by feeding them Chaos Drives and small animals found in the stages, they will grow and take on features of the animals.  Raised Chao can be entered in races, though you have no direct control over their performance outside of a little boost to speed.  There is some incentive to keep going back to the stages to get items to raise the little creatures and it is kinda nice to take care of them and watch them grow and change...and stop drowning in the little pond.

What I Didn't Like
There is a lack of polish with this port, and at times they seemed to fix a couple of things but leave some others strangely untouched.  For example, the wow
date: he's fast hey it's not his speed he's using the Chaos Emerald to warp" line during the story bit when Sonic first meets Shadow IS given a gap
recommended: but the "you're not even good enough--"  "I'll make you eat those words!" before Sonic and Shadow's first fight is not.  The mouths move with the Japanese audio and not with the English which results in some cutting off at times

reviewText:
Sonic adventure 2 is an original port from the Sega dreamcast into HD. The game has 2 sides of the the story which is Hero which has Sonic,Tails and Knuckles and the Dark side having Dr.Robotnik/Eggman, newcomers like Shadow the hedgehog and Rouge the bat. The game consists of 3 different kinds of gameplay: Sonic and Shadow have fast-pace action stages, Tails and Eggman have shooting levels similar to Gamma's shootin levels in Sonic Adventure 1 and Knuckles and Rouge have treasure hunting stages.Oh and the Chao garden makes a return but even better!

Its a very nice looking game considering its in HD. Gameplays outstanding and the story itself takes a whole new level of seriousness (if thats even a word).

If your a huge Sonic fan or just a fan of Dreamcast, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME!

reviewText:
The base game is good and in the moment you'll find yourself caught up in the story. There is a very meaty challenege for anyone trying to 100% the game. I did it on PS3 and really enjoyed it.

Gameplay can be broken down into 4 parts:

Speed: You're Sonic/Shadow you run through levels. The best part of the game.

Shooting: Tails/Eggman are in mechs and you have a lock on lazer cannon the idea of each stage being how many enemies you can target at once before losing the lock, pretty neat once you get into it.

Treasure Hunting: Knuckles/Rouge fly around contained levels looking for 3 of something. You can climb, glide, dig, it's fun to just run around as them really.

There's also a few mods out that are pretty great and I highly recommend hitting up Sonic Retro for them.

Now for a controversial opinion: Chao Garden sucks.
A lot of people will try to tell you the chao portion is something special. It was easily the poorest portion of the game by far. It's tedious, it's annoying, it's not deep or interesting it's a time waster through and through.

Essentially all the enemies in the game drop animals or energy cores that you can give to the chao leveling them up so they can better race or fight. The racing and fighting however are slow paced affairs you have no impact on other than cheering making the whole affair a massive time waster.

In short: Mechanically solid game with an excellent aesthetic, it has a tacked on time waster you need to 100% the game but you can ignore it really.

reviewText: One of the best Sonic games out there. Gives the option to play 3 playstyles. The first is action stages you play as Sonic/Shadow and run through levels at high speed. Second is the mech shooters where you play as Tails/Eggman in mechs. The goal is to go through levels at a slower speed shooting all the enemies. Last and least is the treasure hunting stages. In these satges you play as Knuckles/Rouge to find the shards of the Master Emerald. The gameplay in these stages are very slow and boring. You will go around for minutes trying to find 1 shard. These are the most hated sections of this game. There is also a feature called the Chao Garden. In the Chao Garden you raise chao in 5 stats Flying, Speed, Power, Swimming, and Stamina. These stats help you compete in Chao Races and Chao Karate. This mode can be very complicated and you can spend hours raising chao. Overall this game is a very good reboot of the Dreamcast classic and I recomend buying it.

reviewText:
A great game that has held up to the test of time.But a good port with unresolved issues that Sega has never patched
Recommended Reading http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Sonic_Adventure_2

I LOVE SA2, I was obsessed with this game back when it came out on the DC and later the GCN. My friends and my brother and I all played this endlessly together. It's not perfect, but is a testament and standard to how 3D Sonic games should all be designed.

As imperfections are present in the game, so too are they in the port itself. It's just shy of being great.

Pros Retains the 60FPS performance profile of the original games
Supports arbitrary resolutions of varying aspect ratios. (Multimon setups require Flawless Widescreen FlawlessWidscreen*dot*org)
All gameplay and some cutscenes now support native HOR+ Widescreen (Remaining Cutscenes are 4:3
UI and many textures have been updated and look very clean
Full Controller and Keyboard support with a switch in the launcher for both.
Supports Controller and Keyboard Icons
Supports different Keyboard layout standards. AZERTY,QWERTY,etc
Full Remapping of all buttons and keys
Still supports local MP and content from the GCN Battle release
Performs flawlessly when it works for you

_________________________________________________________
Cons
Game logic is tied to 60FPS. This means if you drop under 60FPS (Would take a low end machine to do so) the game slows down rather than dropping frames. It also means if you have a Variable Refresh Rate Monitor or a High Refresh Rate Monitor, the game will be sped up over 60FPS.
So these users *NEED* to set their monitor to a 60hz RR when playing the game. A simple Framerate cap will not suffice because...

The Steam Overlay, Riva Tuner Statistic Service OSD (From MSI Afterburner), and external Framerate limiters (RTSS,DXTory,GeDoSaTo,etc) will cause the game to crash after the Sonic Team logo appears. (You need to disable the Steam Overlay and add Sonic2app.exe" to RTSS and set the "Application Detection Level" to "None" )
When this happens
date: you have to Crtl+Alt+Del to open Task manager and kill the .EXE. Because...\n\nGame does not support Alt+F4 to quit. So you have to Alt-Tab out
recommended:
or go through the tedious menus in game to quit.
Creating a game profile for Sonic Adventure 2 in Nvidia Control Panel or Nvidia Inspector and enabling FXAA will ALSO cause the game to crash at the Sonic Team Logo
Game does not support any kind of Anti Aliasing on it's own. See below section about AA.
The "Battle" content from the GCN release is tied behind a DLC Paywall.
The launcher always opens with the game. You can bypass it by following the guide "Bypass Launcher" under "Essential improvments" in the linked page at the top.
For some people the game will not launch unless in windowed mode. I myself have never had this problem. YMMV.
No Texture Filtering setting.

The Sound Effects are INSANELY loud and painful to listen to. Overall the Audio balance is extremely poor
hoursPlayed: which is something that is carried over from the original releases I think. Something they SHOULD have fixed in this release or at the very damn least
voteText:
put in Volume Sliders.
Currently the only way to fix it is to extract and modify the sounds of the game directly. Which can be tricky for some.
Luckily someone put together a file with all the sound effects lowered by 50%!

=Download this archive= https://mega.nz/#!MFQwlYJS!fwOdyFTe5JFm9z0ENmFFFjkLT0R7DoYBDkSBBUP9FNs
=navigate <path-to-game> "resource\gd_PC". =
Replace the folder "MLT" with the one from the archive.______________________________________________________________

Now
helpfulPercent: it seems like the Cons are much larger than the Pros. So one would assume the recommendation would be "NO".\n\nBut to the contrary
votesHelpful:
most of them are easily solvable (Now that is) and it doesn't affect enjoyment of the game once you get it up and running and deal with some of the small unavoidable quirks.

____________________________________________________________________________

Tweaks For Nvidia UsersIt is highly recommended you use Nvidia Inspector for Nvidia Users. As it allows greater control on a per profile basis than NVCP. Allows more options to be changed and is FAR more responsive than the sluggish NVCP.

Nvidia Inspector setup guide
Download the latest version here http://www.guru3d.com/files-details/nvidia-inspector-download.html - In the future if the application needs to update. It will tell you so and automatically download any updates.

Save it to a location that you can permanently use. Extract it.

When you open it for the first time you will be presented with http://u.cubeupload.com/MrBonk/InspectorMainScreen.png
Click the Tool icon next to the "Driver Version" Box to open up the driver profile settings.

You are now greeted with this screen and the default "Global Home" Profile
http://u.cubeupload.com/MrBonk/Inspectorbasicexplan.png (You will want to create a desktop shortcut as noted)
These are the settings that globally apply to ANY given application. It is VERY IMPORTANT that you minimize what you force Globally to only basic things such as Texture Filtering settings and Performance Mode.
Here is my Global profile
votesTotal:
I suggest you match it  (Remember to hit "Apply Changes" afterward)and change nothing else.
http://u.cubeupload.com/MrBonk/GlobalProfile.jpg

Sonic Adventure 2 does not have a profile in the Nvidia Drivers by Default
Following the notes on this picture http://u.cubeupload.com/MrBonk/Inspectorbasicexplan.png
Create a new profile named "Sonic Adventure 2"

You are now ready to tweak Anti-Aliasing and HBAO+
*If you matched my Global Profile settings
votesFunny:
you will not need to change any Texture Filtering settings. As the new Profile will match the global setting by default of HQ 16xAF
Sonic Adventure 2 does not require a special Hexidecimal Flag in order to force Anti Aliasing.
It supports forcing of essentially all AA modes.
MSAA
commentsCount: TrSSAA (Transparency SuperSampling)
column16: SGSSAA (Sparse Grid SuperSampling)
column17: OGSSAA (Shown as "YxY Supersampling" modes.Ordered Grid Super Sampling.) and HSAA (Hybrid-Sampling. Which is a combination of MSAA
column18: OGSSAA
column19: TrSSAA and SGSSAA)\n\nMy recommendation if you have a decent GPU is to use "16xS [Combined: 2x2 SS + 4x MS]". This is IMO the best performance/quality ratio option. It's not perfect
column20:
but the average user won't notice the remaining issues.

To see references and how to apply AA settings in Nvidia Inspector see this guide here (That I am the maintainer of)
http://forums.guru3d.com/showthread.php?t=357956

For HBAO+ there are two working flags - 0x00000012 (Subtle) and 0x00000013 (Strong)
Both have some minor bleeding
column21: but add quite a bit of depth.\nTo see references and how to apply HBAO+ in Nvidia Inspector follow my guide with images here\nhttp://forums.guru3d.com/showthread.php?t=387114"

reviewText: One of the best Sonic games out there. Gives the option to play 3 playstyles. The first is action stages you play as Sonic/Shadow and run through levels at high speed. Second is the mech shooters where you play as Tails/Eggman in mechs. The goal is to go through levels at a slower speed shooting all the enemies. Last and least is the treasure hunting stages. In these satges you play as Knuckles/Rouge to find the shards of the Master Emerald. The gameplay in these stages are very slow and boring. You will go around for minutes trying to find 1 shard. These are the most hated sections of this game. There is also a feature called the Chao Garden. In the Chao Garden you raise chao in 5 stats Flying, Speed, Power, Swimming, and Stamina. These stats help you compete in Chao Races and Chao Karate. This mode can be very complicated and you can spend hours raising chao. Overall this game is a very good reboot of the Dreamcast classic and I recomend buying it.

reviewText: Great game.  Horrible port.\n\nDon't get me wrong, I love Sonic Adventure 2, but saying this port isn't optimized is a grand understatement.  It almost feels like SEGA just threw the Dreamcast or Gamecube game into either a horrible emulator or an unfinished emulator.  You can tell just from the opening cinematic in the Battle DLC.  The grind particles, names, and many other effects are way off sync from what's actually going on in the cutscene.  Another problem with emulations is one that can't always be fixed, especially with video/audio intensive games like SA2: the framerate.  I understand that SEGA did emulated games on Steam before, such as Sonic 3 and Knuckles, as well as other companies, such as SQUARE ENIX's Final Fantasy VII and Final Fantasy VIII, but these games are excused.  Why?  Because they are nowhere near as video (or audio) intensive as the game in question, and therefore, there is no lag (and if there is, then why are you even using your horrible computer to play games?).  And I have no problem with framerate drops, usually, as long as it isn't drastic.  The thing about this game's low framerate is that it doesn't skip frames to make up for it; it slows the whole game down.  If you look at the timer in the top-left, you may notice that 1 second seems unusually long.  This is a problem, especially in a game that is all about speed; however, I do have to give credit on one thing: the music and sound effects don't slow down with the framerate, which is very nice.  It would be even nicer if the rest of the game didn't slow down!  All in all, I love this game, but seriously, get the Dreamcast version or Gamecube version, or if you have a PS3 or XBOX360 with internet, you can buy them off of their respective online shops, bringing up one more question: why do those ones run so well?

reviewText: Absolutely awful. Sonic Adventure DX has definitely aged poorly in a few places, but this game makes Sonic Adventure feel like a timeless classic. The camera is way too tight; trying to get a view of what's around your character is next to impossible in some areas. Cutscenes are downright bizarre - characters talk over each other, and I think they outsourced the localization job to the lowest bidder. The Knuckles / Rouge gem finding missions are atrocious - you're constantly fighting the camera; the gem radar has now been changed so you can only get a hint for the location of one emerald at a time. I wouldn't have thought this game was that awful, until I got to the Knuckes portion of the final sequence of the game - imagine that bad camera combined with one of the worst water levels I've ever played.

reviewText:
Okay, so two quick things to mention from what I've seen in other reviews:

One: This is NOT the revolutionizing 3D Sonic Game that came out on the Gamecube. This is the sequel to the TRUE revolutionizing 3D Sonic Game on the DREAMCAST, which was by the same name without the 2.

Two: All the DLC does is unlock the bonus feature of 2P battle that was introduced in the re-make on the Gamecube, so there's nothing really lost by not getting it unless you have two controllers and want to play with somebody else in this glitch-fest.

Anyway, as for my quick little review. While the game itself is stellar, or should be, the PC port is a hunk of dung that I'm glad I didn't buy for it being Sonic Adventure 2. I luckily got it as part of a bigger bundle, and honestly the levels and controls are extremely glitchy on this port and I find myself dying many times because of hitting invisible walls, having my speed inverted, falling through ground, or just plain having my screen turn black for 10 seconds while the video dies despite the game continuing on, which ends up desyncing the audio/video.

As much as I really, truly want to recommend this game, after playing a little bit of it, the glitchiness is just too much to handle. I'm going to try playing some more later, but honestly it's hard to play a game you love when the mechanics of it are as broken as this. If at all possible, play the Gamecube port, and/or the Gamecube port of Sonic Adventure (DX). I'm honestly not sure if it's worth it to play this if you've never played Sonic Adventure (2/battle) before since I feel it will leave a terrible impression upon the two games.

tl;dr
The game itself is amazing, but the engine is broken on PC. People who think this is the ground breaking original 3D game are ill-informed.

reviewText: Its nice to finally see Sonic Adventure 2 on PC. The gameplay is generally fast-paced, and fun. As for the story, its fairly straightforward, and offers two different sides to play. After the story is completed, the Chao Garden feature offers some replay value, if you're interested in caring for the virtual creatures. Gameplay aside, I'm a bit dissappointed with the quality of this port, as SEGA didn't take the opportunity to enhance/remaster any of the art/assets, and it really shows. Additionally, this port requires oddly high specs to run at full speed, especially when Sonic Adventure DX could be played on most basic machines.

reviewText: Back in the day, Sonic Adventure 2 was considered one of the best Sonic games. Today, i can say that this game sucks. Period. To be honest, i had much more fun with the original Sonic Adventure, except for fishing. That game had 6 gameplay styles, but this one has only 3. Sonic and Shadow stages are easily the best part of the game, and the reason many love this game. However, some stages aren't much fun to play, because of the challenge. There's nothing wrong with that, but as a whole i prefer the Sonic stages of the original Sonic Adventure. Do you remember the E-102 Gamma shooting stages? They were only okay, but at least it's story was short. Here, Tails (which i also liked on the original) and Eggman stages are the same, but much longer. It gets boring and repetitive after a while. And the Knuckles stages are back, but are worse for two reasons. First, the radar only shows one piece at a time, so the stages take much longer to complete. Secondly, Rouge stages are the same, so you get more of this bad design choice. Some reviewers said that because only the Sonic and Shadow stages were good, they only enjoyed 33% of the game. But no. The bad stages take a longer time to complete, so i would say that only 20% of the story playtime was fun. On the plus side, the hub world is gone and the bosses are better. The story is improved but still sucks, and the soundtrack for me is much worse than the original. To get all the emblems, you need to replay the stages over and over and over again. It's a chore. But there's more good stuff. The Chao garden is much improved, and this time i actually cared a bit for it. And there's also 2-player multiplayer, which is actually good. I also need to mention that the Steam version is much better optimized that the original mess of Sonic Adventure DX on Steam, only playable with a mod pack. There's also leaderboards if you enjoy that kind of thing. But the Battle" content is locked behind a DLC purchase
date: a terrible practice by SEGA. Despite everything
recommended: in the end i can recommend this game on sale if you enjoyed this game back in the day or if you want the best chao garden version available. For newcomers
hoursPlayed: i recommend to stay away from this game and play the original Sonic Adventure DX instead if you must choose between one of them. Hell
voteText: i think that even Sonic Heroes is a better game."

reviewText:
Warning: I will probably have a bais as someone who has been playing this since I was very small- I have also beated the game numerous times- so I don't feel like I need to discuss it as if i have yet to finish it. I will also not talk about how i feel about the game in regards of the story,graphics,sound, or gameplay. If this isn't a problem to you in regards of the review, keep reading.
-

I have played the GC version for my entire life, so after getting the HD PC port of this i gotta mention three things:
1.They ripped off some features in the game that should be part of the base game (Chao karate, for one)
2.These ripped features can be attainable within the DLC, that you need to buy additionally
3. The 'optional' DLC is required in order to collect ALL the emblems within the game.

in other words, you can't finish the game or even enjoy it to the fullest extent without coughing up an extra couple of bucks or cents (if it goes on sale)
That's pretty f^cking absurd. I'm not even someone who cares to complete a game 100% but forcing people to pay for content that was stripped away from the base game is stingy and undignified.
I can't recommend the game alone if your incentive to play the game is to actually get 100%. If this is not a problem for you- then I'd say go right on ahead - It's still pretty fun if played casually.

I will change my review if they decide to add the 'DLC' into the base game, making the game a complete piece- as it should have been.

reviewText: This game is not as fun as many people say it. I am sorry to all of you who loved this game, but there are so many things that are horrible about this game, that i am surpirsed everyone is ok with it. Now before i go on, i would like to say that this is coming from a massive Sonic the Hedgehog fan and i haven't played it during the days it was released, so because of so much praise it got, like saying that after this game, Sonic's reputation went downhill, but, in my honest opinion, i believe it started with Sonic Adventure games. Anyway, the 1st problem i have with this game are the controls. They are as clunky as hell. Everytime i try to run really fast on Sonic/Shadow section, chances are that i will either hit something or i will fall of the platform and die, because of how uncontrollably fast they are going. The 2nd problem i have with this game is the Camera. That thing has a mind of it's own. I mean, sometimes you can control it by yourself and sometimes it just locks in one position, and when you want to look around to see if there are enemies or not, you will have a bad time. The 3rd problem is the level design. Actually, for the most part, it's good, but there are sometimes unpredictable obstacles that you will be losing life a lot in those parts (Especially at the ARK levels). So, overall, it was more frustrating to play than fun, and i wouldn't recommend to someone who is not a Sonic fan, and even not to Sonic fans who haven't played this game yet.

reviewText:
SEGA decides to give us the game most Sonic fans declare as the best for the PC.
Poorly no online Multiplayer but still a Masterpiece!

Sonic Adventure 2's PC port is way less polished like it's Prequel's counterpart and looks old. But the nice gameplay and story make up for that. The Chao Garden is finally back and luckily didn't change at all, making the game be so much more addicting.

The game runs pretty smooth on a simple Laptop, making it way better than emulating it (Althrough you can't sprint through City Escape with Eggman anymore via Action Replay...)

As a title originally releashed in the early 2000's. Comparing the graphics with other titles like Sonic Generations isn't the best idea. But the game will always simplify the character model whenever you get to far from the camera or in Multiplayer. Making the game SO ugly at times.

The 3 unique ways to play is a step back from the prequel's 6. But without the annoying fishing stages, this is not bad at all. The Sonic and Shadow stages are the typical 'Reach the goal' levels. While Tails and Eggman get the Mech levels originating from Sonic Adventure's E101 Gamma's stages. Knuckles and Rouge hold the treasure hunt levels, which are way more interesting now with every stage holding something special.

Overall, I totally recommend this game for true Sonic fans and 3D platforming gamers.

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure 2 is a classic that brings back huge amounts of nostalgia for me, but in all honesty, the game hasn't aged very well. 3D Sonic games have always been somewhat iffy, and while this title is no exception, its rough moments can still be overlooked.

Putting the Chao Garden aside (one of the best parts of SA2B), the game is pretty decent, though some levels might frustrate or annoy players with questionable design. The plot is a little bit janky at times, and the cutscenes could use a lot of work (oh god... the lip-syncing), but the core gameplay is still very enjoyable. There are a few different game modes as well, so the gameplay tends to remain interesting and avoid repetitiveness.

However, the one part of this game that always brings me back is the Chao Garden. Chao are small, cute creatures you can raise as sort of a side-game, but the garden has a huge amount of depth to it. You can raise and take care of them, enroll them in kindergarten, give them toys to play with, put them in races, they can interact with each other on their own accord, play instruments in bands, and the list goes on. You can raise them to be good or evil, and their appearance and personality will be reflected by it.

If SA2B was a staple of your childhood, then by all means pick it up; it's the exact same game you know and love. If you haven't experienced it before, I would still recommend it (if not just for the Chao Garden), but just be aware that it's far from perfect.

reviewText: The sequel to the Classic Sonic Adventure, Sonic Adventure 2, makes its way for the PC audience.  Featuring new gameplay modes, such as Kart Racing, and piloting Mechs! Expect an epic story mode in this speedy action game.  Still not enough?  The Chao World also returns, with even more content than before!  Raise your own cute chao, a tiny adaptive creature, in any way you want.  You're sure to spend countless hours with them!  Many challenging missions await you, with four extra challenges for each level. You're definitely in for a challenge!  Definitely a must for any fan of 3D Platformers.

reviewText:
I've played and beaten Sonic 2, 3 & Knuckles, CD, Adventure 1 & 2, Heroes, Shadow the Hedgehog, Sonic 2006, 4 Episode 1 & 2, the DS version of Colors, Generations (including the Unleashed levels mod), and nearly finished Lost World, and I have to say... Slowly eroding nostalgia and stockholm syndrome are the only things that keep me playing his 3D outings.

You probably already know whether or not you're going to buy Sonic Adventure 2 before you read a review of it. You most likely played it when you were younger, or are a fan of later Sonic games curious about his past. Reading this might not change your mind, but I can assure you of one thing: This game has not aged well. Sound familiar? Sonic Adventure 1 is the same way, and many of its mistakes apply to the sequel as well.

Sonic Adventure 2 once again tells the story of Dr. Eggman's attempts to rule the world, and Sonic the Hedgehog and co.'s attempts to stop him. This time he's got a plan that might actually work - He's stolen Dr. Evil's laser" from Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me and is holding the world hostage. What for isn't made clear. It's not money. He wants power. But what he plans to do with it once he has it isn't really addressed. Helping him is Shadow the Hedgehog
date: a genetically engineered super hog created by Eggman's grandfather
hoursPlayed: a government spy/jewel theif who doesn't know the meaning of "conflict of interest". The good guys just follow them around trying to stop them. No dreams or ambitions of their own.\n\nThe overall story
voteText: when written in a few non-sarcastic sentences
helpfulPercent: I really like. Seeing that story unfold is like watching a Mystery Science Theater movie without the riffing. The acting is either bad
votesHelpful: or passable by accident (my favorite scene is when Eggman hurts Sonic
votesTotal: and Tails lackadaisically says "I will never forgive you for this"). It's also localized poorly. Often it seems characters are saying whatever is in their mind at that moment rather than having a coherent conversation. There are many instances of odd wordings and sentence structure. The technical issues SA1 had in its cutscenes have been reduced ever so slightly
votesFunny: but many still remain. Lip synching is all over the place. Characters talk over each other
commentsCount: and sometimes
column16: themselves. They make odd movements while talking to one another. It *is* better than SA1
column17: but it's not what I'd call good.\n\nThe game is separated into Hero and Dark storylines. There's no overworld this time
column18: just cutscenes and action stages. Each side has three characters who are basically clones of each other. Sonic and Shadow run through linear levels quickly
column19: with lots of platforming and occasional puzzle solving. Eggman and Tails use mech suits with guns to shoot their way through too-complex platforming stages. Knuckles and Rouge search for Master Emerald shards (or other items) in non-linear levels that quickly become too large for their own good.\n\nSonic Team did seem to learn a few lessons from SA1. Sonic and Shadow's levels are laid out like racetracks. Minimal side paths and long straight stretches where you can run freely. These are easily the most fun levels to play. Camera issues are minimalized by not having lots of corners and objects in the way. But they added some new design issues. Both can do a Light Speed Dash to zip along a line of rings. It helps you get around
column20: but it shares a button with both a somersault attack and the spin dash move. There will be many
column21: MANY times where you'll go to spin dash and will instead be flung at some nearby rings
column22: or try to use some rings to get over a gap and will instead somersault right over the edge. Sonic also has a bounce move that shares the same button
column23: so a mistimed Light Speed Dash in the air means instant death. Technical issues with basic movement are still shared with SA1 as well
column24: so slight variations in ground height or angle will cause energetic spasms in your character.\n\nTails and Eggman play much like E-102 Gamma did in SA1. They shoot their way through levels
column25: using a targeting laser to mark enemies for destruction. For some reason I don't mind the sound much
column26: but it does make a high pitched tone whenever you do this
column27: which will be all the time. The level layouts themselves are more complex than the hogs'
column28: and this does not work in their favor. Sonic is supposed to be about going fast
column29: and the mech suits Eggman and Tails inhabit move slow. The later levels often have closed gates that you have to locate the switches for before you can proceed
column30: which makes them take even longer. Basic movement is still riddled with technical issues. Early on you gain the ability to extend your jumps by hovering
column31: but lightly brushing up against a wall will cause you to plummet downwards instantly
column32: causing many accidental deaths. Camera problems are also in full effect when in tight areas. The camera does not get stuck nearly as often as it used to in SA1
column33: but it often manages to find just the wrong angle for the jump you're trying to make or the enemy you're trying to target. That said
column34: it *IS* better than SA1's camera. It feels like they actually played the levels and tried to choose somewhat reasonable angles.\n\nKnuckles and Rouge's levels are scavenger hunting affairs that mirror Knuck's levels from SA1. These are my least favorite levels to play because of one stupid design decision: the proximity detector that used to show any item of interest in range now only shows one at a time. It artificially inflates the time you spend wandering around
column35: and I hate it. This doesn't matter much for the first few levels
column36: since they are small. But both of their final levels take place in space
column37: and are huge. If you haven't been playing these levels since you were 13 like I have
column38: you can easy spend 45+ minutes in them
column39: going in futile circles until you reset the level in the hopes of getting better item locations (like I did when I was 13). The level designs are often confusing. One of Knuckles' levels takes place in an underground mine and involves changing water levels to open paths to different mine shafts. The tight spaces are great for getting the camera blocked in bad angles. Rouge's final level takes place in space near planetoids that will gravitationally attract you. It's like Mario Galaxy
column40: but worse. Both characters are capable of gliding
column41: and climbing on certain walls. There's a new attack in this game
column43: that lets you dive downwards while gliding
column44: and it's actually pretty good. It looks cool
column46: and lets you dig in the ground for items.\n\nThe Chao garden returns
column47: and it has the same system as in SA1DX. I don't really care for the Chao garden
column48: but it doesn't detract from the main game
column49: so I don't mind it existing.\n\nUpsides? Like most Sonic games
column50: the music is pretty good. Live & Learn
column51: and especially the vocal theme to Sonic's first level
column53: are songs I own outside the game. Sonic's Metal Harbor stage also has a ska-like track that is my personal favorite from the game. Even when not memorable
column54: the stage music always matches the stage environment well. *Sometimes* the graphics can be impressive
column55: mostly when they use actual photographs as textures
column56: though the polygon count is still pretty low. The final boss battle
column57: featuring Super Sonic and Super Shadow in space trying to stop a giant lizard from destroying the Earth while Live & Learn plays is genuinely exciting. If you really memorize Sonic and Shadow's levels
column58: you can actually have some fun with this game. Their abilities make sense with the level design
column59: even if they're all mapped to one button.\n\nYou already know whether or not you're going to buy this game. SA2 has more fun potential than SA1
column60: but can also be much more frustrating. They both average out to being pretty bad games. I still play them
column61: because I'm a true Sonc fan. I stick with him through the bad times. Nostalgia aside
column62: I wish there were more good times to be had with him."

reviewText:
I'll admit this is one of the most nostalgic games for me. I occasionally listen to the OST still to this day and might leave the soundtracks on repeat for hours at a time. I'm also part of that group of people who thinks this is one of the better 3D games for Sonic, mechanically. It's true that newer Sonic 3D games have improved on many of the unique issues that arise when developing for a unique character like Sonic, but the gameplay in SA2:B just feels the most controllable. I admit the breakneck speed effects of more recent Sonic games feel more genuine to the character, but this one game still feels the most controllably fluid for me. Then again that might just be more of the nostalgia showing.

Unfortunately, I think this is one of those games that you don't really like until you've played through it a couple times and have a good feel for the quirky camera and the level layouts and upgrade collections - and a game controller (you really ought to play this one with a game controller).

The story wasn't all that amazing to me as a kid and holds even less value to me today - however the premise of Sonic still having an actual attitude and characters having personality archetypes that relate to their traditional reasons for existing, beyond filling a role as [acquaintances of the protagonist character]
date:
is something that makes me perhaps a bit dissapointed with the direction of the franchise since such days of the past.

All the Sonic fandom crap aside - Generally speaking, I'd recommend this game to anyone with a game controller and a thing for arcade games.

Edit: After playing this on PC with an xbox controller for a few hours - I hate to say it, but it handles much worse than I recall from the Gamecube. So much easier to get caught off-course and have a sudden momentum halt just from gently swiping a polygon the wrong way. It's definitely not as enjoyable as my nostalgia recalls. I may set up the gamecube again someday to compare how the GC version plays against the PC version - it definitely feels different in a bad way. In addition to the controls feeling really over-sensitive, the game has several audible and visual glitches that are new to me - most occuring during the rouge/knuckles maps where you tend to observe the maps in detail while seeking the hidden pieces.

reviewText:
I would say this is a great Sonic game, but it does have it's problems which I will strike up later.

---Overview---
Out of every Sonic Game I have ever played, this one in paticular just didn't seem to cross my mind to playing it til now. You know what I mean, Tails riding in a mecha armor suit and... Eggman as a playable char?? This game was sending me all kinds of negative signals and I ceased to playing it until this day.

----Presentation----
After playing SA1, alot of things were noticably changed. Instead of 6 seperate storylines (not counting final stage) we have only 2 story modes. That seemed ok to me at first and I started the Heroes story without question. The one thing that cought me by surprise was that 3 characters had their own seperate stages and they were all diferent and unique. I'm looking at you, Knuckles. Those haunting missions appear so frequent that it makes me wish on why they just didn't make those stages optional.
As you get closer to the end of the game, the stages get more difficult and... weirder. There will be a time where you will be in a tight situation and you have no lives, so good luck there.
The cut scenes look like an imrpovemt from SA1 in my opinon. Lip syncing is more accurate and... Tails, that mouth! What have they done to you? Alright, I agree the characters looked a bit weird talking in SA1 but atleast some of the graphic look of most characters in that game had actual mouths. Here it's just him using his whiskars or something, it's weird.
I think so far the only favorite part I like in this game is Sonic's first stage, Escape the City
date:
which is one of my favorite music tunes, it never gets old.

----Overall----
Alright I think you all know what I think of this game at this point, but it's not a bad game. It's just one of those games you may need to sit down and get used to. Not an On-The-Go game like SA1 was. SA2 will challange you and I just don't think this game is the way to go for newcomers. The camera angle in some areas can get so obnoxius that it may just drive you insane if not get very anoyyed by it.

----Personal Score----
4.5/10

This is a BAD PORT of a once good game, and i honestly cannot reccomend it. Save your childhood memories and save your money too.

reviewText:
Everyone's favorite 3D Sonic game. Has everything that people look for in Sonic.

Cons
-------
-Drunk camera.
-Physics that don't make any ♥♥♥♥ing sense at all.
-A story made of cardboard.
-♥♥♥♥-tier vehicle segments.
-♥♥♥♥-tier hide-and-seek segments (At least they were kind of amusing in SA).
-A timed hide-and-seek segment (pls go).
-Fake speed.
-OC donut steel shadow the edgehog
-Bosses are a chore
-Chao garden isn't really nearly as entertaining as people insist it is, and deep down inside everyone knows it

Pros
-------
+It's playable
+Most of the sonic levels are fun when the camera isn't being a ♥♥♥♥
+One or two of the shadow levels are fun when the physics engine isn't being a ♥♥♥♥
+The music
+The moon gets blown in half
+I'm really trying my best to come up with pros here


I've tried my best to like this game, but it really isn't that good.

reviewText:
As fantastic as it was on the Dreamcast and GameCube. Although there are some flaws.

- Audio isn't bad, but sometimes the audio comes in too early or late. And sometimes it just outright cuts out (Ex: The police at the end of the cutscene after Sonic's first boss battle) There are also times where the speaking has little feeling or feels unnatural. I know it's a game about a super-fast blue hedgehog, but the audio could be a LITTLE better (even if is one of the first fully voiced Sonic games).

- The controls for the PC could be a bit better. I understand that you can map the controls; that's what I did. Still, the PC controls don't work as well for certain aspects. For example, although it isn't terrible, Sonic and Shadow's homing attacks are a bit hard to control. You have to have almost exact aiming with WASD keys (if that's what feels natural for you; otherwise, it's whatever keys you mapped moving to) to be able to hit the target you want. Also, I feel the movement of the mouse could've been utilized for Tails/Eggman missions for aiming their laser.

- While the Knuckles/Rouge missions aren't the worst levels in gaming, I'm going to be blunt: I hated them. They were too repetitive and annoying. I feel a better concept for these missions could've been created other than the emeralds are lost
date: use your radar to track them down in the least time possible". Maybe they could use their respective punch/kick attacks to actually
hoursPlayed: destroy enemies (which were actually kind of rare to find in these missions) and use their glide abilities to get to other platforms to reach the end of the level? Maybe not that
voteText: but something more engaging than a boring treasure hunt mission.\n\n- Multiplayer being DLC. Need I say more? Crappy decision

reviewText:
- Sonic stages: Fun, but later on the game foolishly tries to introduce new mechanics for individual levels that slow down the flow that makes the early levels great.

- Knuckles stages: Awful treasure hunts with seemingly every poor level design choice for this kind of gameplay under the sun.

- Tails stages: BEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEP KABOOM BEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEP KABOOM (repeat for eternity)

Dark mode is just a reskin of these stage types.

This game started the great decline in quality of the 3D Sonic platformers that was only really healed by Colours and Generations. And it spawned the terrible part of the Sonic fanbase with its story that is really dumb and tries way too hard to be hardcore and edgy.

Don't waste your money on this overrated drivel. I only got it as part of a collection offer because I wanted SADX (a flawed but far superior game) and Sonic Generations (Really, REALLY good) I knew going in that SA2B was flawed, but many people loved it, so I gave it a chance. I gave it a chance until I finished the ♥♥♥♥er. Don't believe what those fanfic writers say. This game is just awful.

2/10 had like two good levels.

reviewText: I wanted to like this game. I'm sad that I can't like this game.\n\nSonic Adventure 2 is considered one of the greatest 3D Sonic games of all time. I have played it before and I thought it was good. However, I recommend you play the game on anything BUT PC. First of all, the controls are only labled during the part when you can change your resolution, which was unacceptable for me. If you can even get the game to play, you'll soon know that the controls are aweful, especially for PC. Even after changing them multiple times, the game was very hard then what I remember playing it on the gamecube. In fact, the controls are SO BAD that I can't even get past THE FIRST BOSS OF THE GAME. Not only that, but the games crashes and freezes, which is very frustrating. I recommend that you use a controller IF YOU CAN EVEN FIND ONE THAT IS COMPATIBLE. As far as I know, the only controller that works with this is the Xbox 360 Controller, which means if you don't own an Xbox 360, you'll have to pay something like $50 to just play this game okayer. Hopefully, they decide to make more controllers compatible in the future, but I highly doubt that SEGA will add that into a future update. Until then, I recommend to not get this game on PC, but on something like the gamecube or Dreamcast.

That being said, don't buy this game if your PC is crappy, or runs on Intel graphics. Otherwise...
YOU'RE TOO SLOW!!!!!!!!!

Final Rating: Fast/Pootis + Spooky x Fish

BATTUL MOAD REVUE:
If you have a friend, sibling, or cousin who lives nearby and loves this game, BUY IT RIGHT NOW!!!!
If you live alone, I wouldn't  reccomend it, since there's no Online Matchmaking.

Final Rating: Semi-Fast/Pootis + Spooky x Fish

reviewText:
I have many problems with Sonic Adventure 2, but my largest is that the art direction in general is much worse than most previous Sonic titles and the level variety is very weak. You have city levels, mechanical levels, forests, pyramid levels (which are very creative) and not much else, whereas Sonic Adventure 1 had a little of everything players could want. I understand why they removed the overworld from the first game as well, but I think it was a mistake abandoning the concept completely. The music is not as good as the first game's soundtrack either, but it is enjoyable enough; I especially enjoyed how each character's levels had their own genre of music too. The story is simply a mess, but is easy to ignore.

As a pure 3D platformer the game is largely mediocre. I feel the Sonic levels are more 'solid' in design than any other 3D Sonic title, but everything else feels significantly worse and less fun to me than the first Sonic Adventure. Most zones are significantly larger and infinitely more elaborate, making the scoring for the hardcore fans potentially more enjoyable, but much more frustrating and tedious for those interested in casual play.

I would recommend the game to people who are interested in revisiting levels to improve their rank and finding various secrets though. I think the scoring system in the game is brilliant and very undervalued by many. No Sonic game since has had such a balanced, thoughtful scoring system. The Chao raising is very addicting if you allow yourself to get absorbed in it too.

I do enjoy Sonic Adventure 2 and have fond memories of unlocking everything on the SEGA Dreamcast version back in the summer of 2001. I could never do it again (or would I want to), but I am very nostalgic of those times.

reviewText:
I'll review this as a port. The game itself is fantastic and one of the best games of the dreamcast/gamecube library.

-Some of the cutscenes are still pre-rendered. And by that, I mean they came straight from the Dreamcast. Numerous times, I saw some of the cutscenes run in 4:3, while the gameplay is 16:9. That shows Sega laziliy ported this game.

-Camera controls feel off. You rotate the camera by pressing RT or LT(I use an xbox 360 controller). However, pushing RT, rotates the camera to the left of your character and vice versa, and the camera will only move horizontally. A handful of times, the camera will point at a fixed angle.

-Except for adjusting resolution, there are no graphical settings at all.

-The same goes for audio settings. The only settings available are language spoken and mono/stereo.

-You cannot change the interface language while running the game. You could in the Dreamcast and Gamecube versions, so why take that out?

-The music is untouched from the original DC/GC version, which I find to be a mixed feeling. It's nice that they kept all the songs, and listening to the familar tunes brings back memories, but an updated soundtrack would've been better.

-The multiplayer battle mode is DLC, which is a huge red flag in my book. Battle mode was available from the start in the GC version, and should be available from the start in this version.

-Customizable menu has also been locked out as DLC. Is Sega turning into Capcom now?

-In some of the cutscenes, the lip sync is a bit off. Again, Sega is being lazy with the port.

I recommend getting this game only if:
1. You've never played it before
2. You don't have a Gamecube or Dreamcast
3. You're like me and love it enough to buy it a second time

reviewText:
I want to take you back to a simpler time in your life. Remember when you were in middle school sitting at the lunch table, and you were wolfing down your peanut butter and jelly sandwich as quickly as you can to maximize your time at recess? Remember smelling a faint note of rat ♥♥♥♥ wafting in from the corner like a fart-filled Hindenburg, waiting to immolate your sinuses? Remember turning to meet your nasal assassin, only to see half a cafeteria of barely-pubescent corpses strewn about the tables? One last child stood amongst the carnage and held the herald of your salvation in his hands. The cold barrel of his father's gun met your lips as his hand trembled incessantly... your first kiss. You thought it'd be more romantic.

The least important of these questions is whether or not he decided to pull the trigger. The only question that remains after the police tape goes up is: why? Why, when so much of life was ahead of us all, would he decide to close the curtain so soon?

Sonic Adventure 2 is a comprehensive study in the stimuli that cause these tragedies. What must a child have witnessed to decide that candy and gameboys were no longer in his taste, but that blood would make a fitting substitute? The awful level design of this game leave the mind feeling trapped. Like a cornerned animal, its option to flee has been rescinded and its only recourse is to lash out at anything and everything that stands in a direct line between their current position, and the glowing red exit sign. The exit sign that was once a part of the scenery now becomes a glowing beacon of salvation that's never seemed so distant.

And what of the incessant sound effects: the beeping, the horrendous voice acting, the awful music that's good" because it's "ironically bad?" Well... if you need to know more about that
date: just ask the sinners in the deepest circle of Hell whose ears were shattered by the bloodcurdling screams of their family.\n\nThe chao garden's pretty cool though."

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure 2 is a bad game. Full stop. The music is great and there's some sections, particularly the justifiably iconic City Escape level, which capture a nice since of speed that can be interesting, but the fickle camera and controls (I'm baffled by the fact that these actually got worse from Sonic Adventure rather than better), awkward character movement, complete lack of polish, repetitive Tails / Eggman levels, and outright torturous Knuckles / Rouge levels bring everything that is good about this game far, far down. Even the Sonic / Shadow levels, inarguably the game's highlight, aren't consistently enjoyable.

Stripped of the novelty, hype, and impressive graphics that Sonic Adventure 2 possessed when it first came out on the Dreamcast, it becomes obvious that this is a janky and poorly designed platformer which doesn't hold a candle to Super Mario 64 or its 2D predecessors. And despite this being a sequel to an iconic platformer, those platforming bits - which are the best parts of the game even if that isn't saying a lot - only make up less than a third of your play time. The entire rest of the game is worse and you spend far too much time doing things that have no relation to traditional Sonic gameplay. The later Knuckles levels can drag on for in excess of 35 minutes, making the game's absolute worst moments also it's most drawn out ones. At least the mech levels are marginally less glitch prone than Sonic's running ones. Not as if that's saying much. On the plus side of things, with some belated updates, the port is actually pretty solid even if it doesn't fix the game's original problems.

Nostalgia purchasers only. Grab Sonic Generations if you're looking for a modern Sonic game that is actually pretty good (and, as a bonus, doesn't feel the need to constantly force you to play as anyone but Sonic).

reviewText:
This is one of the worst games I've ever played.

The game starts out fun, with city escape being a selling point alone if the game was on sale. After that, the game quickly becomes terrible. The tails/eggman and knuckles/rouge stages are completely boring, filled with tedious platforming and combat. The Sonic/Shadow stages, while sharing the same complaints, are better designed than the other stages. However, they also have the homing attack, which will either function or screw you over. Every time I died I felt it was the game's fault.

There are also cutscenes within the game, which have some cringe-worthy voice acting and dialogue tied in with out-of-sync talking animations. The game's plot, for some reason, has some dark themes that you wouldn't expect from a sonic game. The soundtrack is the only redeeming feature for this game, having some memerable tracks if you aren't playing a knuckles/rouge stage (seriously, hip hop?)

However, I haven't even talked about the monstrosity that is the pc port. First off, the pc port, despite saying so in the controls section of the launcher, does not support xbox 360 controllers (I assume the same goes for every other gamepad), which means you have to play through a 3d sonic game without a gamepad. I've also encountered many minor bugs along with forum users suggesting that there are major bugs that I haven't encountered.

Pros
Soundrack (Trust me and we will escape from the city!)

Cons
Everything else

In short, even if you enjoyed the gameplay as a kid, DO NOT BUY THE PC VERSION! My hatred of the gameplay may just be opinion, but the buggy mess that is this pc port is unacceptable. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED...

reviewText:
I really don't find it fun or enjoyable to play at all. I went into the game with a clear mind-set, forgetting about Sonic's infamous reputation for terrible 3D games (Sonic 06..) but I still thought it was just... Eugh. Which is weird. I was expecting probably the best 3D Sonic game, as many reviews claim, but that's far from what I got.

The voice acting is terrible, even for a sonic game. The controls are clunky, sonic seeming to turn more quickly than you expect - even with an xbox gamepad. As established by Sonic 06, Sonic just doesn't suit 3D gaming.

Honestly, get it if you enjoyed it as a kid - But seeing as it's not a nostalgia trip for me, it's just not that great of a Sonic game, let alone a video game at all.

reviewText: when i heard about sonic adventure is hyped out of my mind because i enjoyed many parts of sonic adventure and the things i hated about the game where still in the game its a shame that sonic team has no idea how to make a good game because sonic adventure 2 is far from a good game sonic adventure let me explain\n\nSonic adventure 2 has many great moments that builds up the hype and keeps the game going however its just not a good game in the manner of a good game the game is awful in almost every aspect of a video game its really a shame when some parts are done so well that Adventure 2 falls on its face every time you play a level without speed its a very big issue in the game the biggest issue i have in this game is the camera in the steam version you can only move it left and right its a nightmare to even move about 3 steps because the camera centers its self its moved its a big deal when you a moving at a faster pace with Sonic or Shadow's levels because the camera moves while you are moving it can give you the worst possible angle at times not even seeing the objective another issue is the game play of rouge and knuckles while in the first game hunting for chaos emeralds was fun and mostly fast now the system is extremely frustrating and half-♥♥♥♥♥ the game requires you to find chaos emeralds in a proper order unlike sonic adventure where you could get the emeralds in any order however sonic team wanted the levels to drag on longer that is not the main issue the levels are not well designed at very bland and boring to look at when sonic adventure's goal was to make the level pretty and fun to play this time the game is a complete opposite to sonic adventure make you have a bad time while looking at extremely plain and boring levels another big issue i have is the controls while while mostly everybody controls well Tails and Eggman controls are wretched the main reason is because the games levels for sonic and eggman are meant for sonic and shadow they and painfully slow and the game doesn't get any better in the level design for tails and eggman levels the levels are painfully slow and tedious also the enemy placements are just cheap i can't recall the number of times where i had about 200 rings and where a enemy just lands on top of me and i lose all my rings forcing me to do the level again if i want a better score however this a problem with all characters if you want the highest score in a level you will need to complete some tasks like get a certain amount of rings or kill all baddies in a stage to not dying once in a stage this is a extremely hard task because the game doesn't tell you this i beat the first stage in about 2:30 and got a c rank then a figured out i need to kill more enemy and get more rings forcing me to start the level over again my #1 problem with this game is blatantly unresponsive controls for example as sonic or shadow you can do a light speed dash however this works at the most 30% of the time because the buttons are assigned to the same control input also the homing attack never worked for me believe it or not sonic adventure 2 has some excellent content even better than most games today first of all the music is decent with a more rock theme with the speed stages then the prequels and a lot more electric guitar the main song live and learn is by far the best song in the game however many other songs such as emerald hunting is just out of place with odd rapping music in the background its pretty enjoyable music its just it doesn't fit with the theme of the level my main issue with the music it isn't as memorable as the prequel the game also has a great story i really enjoyed it also the new hedgehog shadow is maybe the best part of this game so overall Sonic Adventure 2 isn't the best game but again its not the worst game while it has many promising moments and the gameplay can  be dull and boring at times the speed levels and the only reason to buy this game its pretty cheap also its just the game doesn't fix the problems of the 1999 original its a shame there is much potential in this game its not done well i can't recommenced the game with all of these problems however if its on sale I'd say its almost worth it if you stand the boring level design of the 4 playable characters also another good thing about this game is the chao garden its worth it for the game alone its a very fun interactive area of the game so buy it when its on sale and only when its on sale don't spend much on it

reviewText:
Much like its predecessor, Sonic Adventure, Sonic Adventure 2 just copies and pastes all the problems from the previous game and doesn't improve anything.

Pros:
- Only stages that are enjoyable are Sonic's and Shadow's.


Cons:
- Horrible plot.
- Knuckles/Rouge and Tails/Dr. Eggman stages.
- Physics are broken.
- Characters cut off each other in English narration.
- BEST SANIC GAME EVUUUR YOU GUYS" type of Sonic fa-gs defening this game.
- Controls are sometimes horrible.
- Camera is STILL a piece of sh-it.
- Chao Garden is for autistic little kids. Ironically enough
date: grown men like this sh-it as well and will do anything to defend their precious Autistic Garden.\n\nOnly for nostalgic idiots. Hasn't aged well

reviewText: In this incredible sequel, Sonic the Hedgehog, Tails the Fox, Knuckles the Echidna, and friends once again face their deadliest foes from Sonic Adventure. You'll battle Vince the Poorly Placed Camera, Randall the Incoherent Translation, and many other classic Sonic Adventure characters. Lucy the Unnecessary Overworld is gone, but when you reach the space levels you'll face a far more fiendish opponent, Bernice the Unmarked Gravity Discontinuity. My favorite, though, is Vince's new sidekick, Puddles the Sudden Close-up, who steals the show in many of the boss battles.\n\nEDITED TO ADD: Oh, also you fight some robots sometimes, but they're basically harmless.
voteText: 15 of 34 people (44%) found this review helpful 29 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure 2: Battle was a game I loved and played for years in my early teens. It was good for it's time but it has aged pretty poorly. It's not a BAD game, but it's not a good game anymore either really, just okay.

First of all, I have to mention that this game only works with Xbox controllers, which is a pain.

Now to the game itself. The main bulk of it consists of three gameplay types. Sonic and Shadow have the Sonic gameplay you'd expect, Tails and Eggman are in mechs. If you've played Sonic Adventure, it's similar to E-102 Gamma's levels. Finally, Knuckles and Rouge search for treasure. There's also Chao Garden (the most addictive part of the game, if you're into raising little critters), and the kart racing. Hoo boy, It's the WORST part of the game, I have no idea why Sonic Team thought it was a good idea to begin with.

Towards the end of the game, all the final levels have stupid buggy control issues. Sonic/Shadow's homing attack glitches out far too much, and Knuckles/Rouge's space levels take far too long to complete.

Despite this negative sounding review I did enjoy replaying the game for the most part, but I also feel that there are too many issues with this game that I ignored when I was younger simply because I had poor taste. Overall I guess I would only recommend this game to people looking for a nostalgia fix or a surprisingly deep pet game that lasts for hours with an okay Sonic game added on. Otherwise, go play Sonic Colours or Sonic Generations, as those are the better 3D Sonic games.
