reviewText:
Power Changes Everything.

An Advanced World

Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare takes place in a plausible future in which technological progress and today’s military practices have converged with powerful consequences.
In this carefully researched and crafted vision, Private Military Corporations (PMCs) have become the dominant armed forces for countless nations outsourcing their military needs, redrawing borders and rewriting the rules of war.
And Jonathan Irons, the founder and president of the world’s largest PMC - Atlas Corporation - is at the center of it all.

An Advanced Soldier

Powerful exoskeletons evolve every aspect of a soldier’s battle readiness, enabling combatants to deploy with an advanced lethality and eliminating the need for specialization.
The introduction of this gameplay mechanic delivers enhanced player movement and verticality through boost jumps and grappling, covert cloaking abilities, and biomechanics that provide unparalleled strength, awareness, endurance, and speed.
With the advent of the exoskeleton and newly advanced armor and weaponry, every soldier commands tactical freedom in any terrain unlike ever before, fundamentally changing the way gamers play Call of Duty across all modes.

An Advanced Arsenal

Harnessing the power of next-gen platforms, Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare introduces a new hi-tech, advanced arsenal and ability set, arming players with all-new equipment, technology, perks, and vehicles like hoverbikes and highly specialized drones.
Players can also choose between standard ammunition and an all-new class of directed-energy weaponry that enables totally new gameplay dynamics.
And with exoskeletons delivering a massive force multiplier and unprecedented tactical freedom, Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare evolves every firefight.

reviewText:
My history with the Sonic series goes back over a decade. I've stuck with it and tried to keep an open mind through each of the games released from the mid-2000s to mid-2010s whose reception has, for the most part, been unspectacular. Even if Sega's ideas for the colorful creatures haven't always worked - and I will still contend that many games released during this time have - I very much respect them for branching out and flicking an angular, latex-gloved bird at the industry trend of using statistics to decide what kinds of games to create. So it's really a formality, after all, for me to review possibly the last Sonic game that's consistently respected. And boy, have I ever had a lot of fun with the game, so here it goes:

Sonic Adventure 2 has some serious problems.

The game's sunny, San Francisco-esque first level, City Escape, is unique but completely fitting. I've played through it dozens of times trying for the elusive A-rank and completing subsequent missions, and dozens more just for the sheer fun of it. The majority of later levels, though, are much less impressive.

Tails' and Eggman's offerings - the style is identical - are intelligence-insulting, slow, repetitive shoot-'em-up excursions that encourage the player to tap the shoot button for several minutes on end as fast as possible while executing platforming stunts with oddly realistic physics amidst, more often than not, vast expanses of abyss. To be fair, later levels do contact the player's brain for directions once in a while, as shooting certain hatches or covers can expose the level to the universe outside and thus suck the player in. I'm pretty sure that's not how gravity works, but forgivable. What's less forgivable is just how annoying this mechanic is; after being trained to shoot until I can physically shoot no more, I don't much appreciate being slapped in the face by a quick death.

Knuckles' and Rouge's levels I rather enjoy - the ones on Earth, anyway. Those feature much more interesting and varied scenery and more concise, inspired level design. No, it's not speedy, but I don't really miss that. Aside from some abysmal physics in parts of the level Mad Space, Emerald-hunting levels generally play very fluidly and without issue. They're also quite relaxing and force the player to get more intimate with Sonic levels than they may be used to.

Sonic's and Shadow's will likely feel the most familiar to players of not only the Genesis Sonics, but of other 3D titles as well; Sega decided this was the formula that worked the best. For the most part, they're right; the levels are exhilarating, expecting speed and precision as only levels in the Sonic series do. My enthusiasm, unlike Omochao's to help the player, however, is finite: the hedgehog levels occasionally display awkward physics and glitches, and the precision necessary to avoid cheap deaths can get ridiculous. Play or watch a Let's Play of one of the rail levels (particularly Sky Rail) or get acquainted with the homing attack - there's a narrow window of time and distance from a target when you have to press the jump button to neither plummet to your death nor get hit and fall backwards to your death - and you'll see what I mean. Hedgehog gameplay is fun overall, but it's imperfect.

It's high time now for me to talk about what I find by far the worst aspect of the game: the cutscnes. Sweet mother of Wisps, are they ever bad. I get that Sonic Adventure 2 is a Japanese game, but there's non-native but kawaii and starting every other sentence with 'But
date: '" and then there's "voice actors literally interrupting each other and tire-hopping through their already stilted dialogue as they pitifully try to map it to the natural rhythm of the English language." In one scene

reviewText:
Ladies and gentleman, welcome to Sonic Adventure 2.

This is one of the worst games I've ever touched and should be on the Top 100 worst video games of all time, if there is one. The graphics are horribly bad, a downgrade from SADX. This game, it's just so bad and has so much flaws! The controls are horrible. The Knuckles stages are downright torture, the Tails stages are just button mashing!

The specs have to be pretty high to run this game, which shows this port was HORRIBLY optimized. I mean, come on, it's a DREAMCAST game. You don't need a 2.4 ghz processor, jeez. This specs might not seem high, but these are really high for a Dreamacast port. A DREAMCAST PORT! Oh, and if you say the speed stages are good, think twice. The camera is awful, since you don't have control of it! The level design, especially Green Forest's, makes me have a hard time going fast, and it's not fun. How is this nostalgaic? Excuse my grammar of the word nostalgia.

I don't understand! How does this appeal to anyone? I can't find any pros for this game. All I see are cons, cons, cons! This game is so awful, so horrendously bad, I can't describe it! This is the most overatted game I ever played. I do NOT reccomend this game to any Sonic fan. This game is worse than Sonic 06, and Sonic Adventure 2 was completed! To be honest, the controls in 06 felt more complete than Adventure 2. At least I have control of the camera! Also, why does everyone like Live and Learn? It's poorly written and obviously the writing for the song, and the plot itself was rushed. Don't waste your money on this port.

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure Dos is a game about a green hedgehog who is living life outside of the societal norms. He is wanted by the police from the start of the game, goes on to assault multiple officers of the law, and never has to pay for his crimes against society. All the while, the evil Dr. Eggman is trying to bring justice and order to the world, but when a larger force brings Sonic and his criminals to justice, Eggman sides with Sonic's criminal behavior in order to try to save the world. Thus proving the incompetence of everyone involved, since they couldn't kill a stupid hedgehog who is a menace to society.

This game features many things that previous Sonic games didn't have. First off, we have the music. Unlike previous Sonic games, the music in this game is made by Skrillix, who is known for being hip with the kids with his rockin dubstep. But instead of dropping the bass, he picked one up and wrote the theme to City Escape, entitled City Escape 1. It's grating on the ears and reminds us all that suicide is a definite answer.

Next are the 3D controls, remember when Sonic controlled well in a 3D environment? No? That's because that never happened. Sonic Adventure proved that Sonic was a terrible franchise, and Sonic Adventure 2 reinforced that idea. The controls for this game reqiure you to hang upside down with one hand taped to the controller, and the other taped to your ♥♥♥♥. In order to maximize results, you should occassionally dip your head into a bucket of water, since it will remind you of the terrible choices you made leading up to you playing this game.

Finally we have the story. I'm sure everyone plays Sonic for it's rich story environment. But this story involves things that children should not dabble in, assault on officers of the law, prostitution to get emeralds, and stealing. If I didn't know better, I would say that this game was designed to be for young black children to get a head start in their lives. Not to mention, all the levels with Knuckles have some urban black kid music playing.

I give this game a 3/10 for promoting gang violence and treating blacks like people.

reviewText: Unlike some other great Dreamcast titles, Sonic Adventure 2 is a game that has aged about as well a glass of milk in the sun. Loose controls, muddy textures, and an awkward camera help create a mostly uncomfortable experience when compared to more modern 3D platformers. The voice acting is terrible, but at times falls into So bad it's good" territory. Perhaps worst of all are the boring and tedious Knuckles/Rouge levels which could be considered crimes on par with human trafficking.\n\nWhereas Jet Set Radio and NiGHTS Into Dreams are two classic Sega titles that have received the HD treatment and still hold up quite nicely in terms of both their visuals and their gameplay
date: Sonic Adventure 2 wasn't nearly as fortunate. If you have fond memories playing it on the Dreamcast as I did
recommended: it might be best to leave them be and not risk wiping them away."

reviewText: Sonic Adventure 2 has an incredible reputation behind it, with many deeming it the best Sonic game ever created. While perhaps the most stylish, it is also poorly dubbed (with characters frequently interrupting and cutting each other off), requires you to complete the infuriatingly frustrating Knuckles, Rouge, Eggman and Tails levels to get to this game's little bit of meat, suffers from the Sonic series' infamous slew of bugs, and seems to constantly attempt to top itself in chauvinism. Even if you can look beyond the flaws of the game itself (as many have), or beat the game enough that you can just do the Sonic and Shadow stages, you have to be ready for this interpretation of the game to frequently disconnect due to its requirement of always on DRM that frequently malfunctioned on my machine (ironically making it easier to play a pirated copy of this game than a legitimate one).\n\nThis is a very disappointing sequel to the fantastic Sonic Adventure, which unless you're the most die-hard of Sonic fans, I suggest you avoid at all costs (especially the PC version).

HORRIBLE!!!  I wouldn't play this if you PAID me $25 an hour to do so - it is literally that bad.

- The sound and music are god-awful making you want to stab out your ear drums

- The graphics are beyond atrocious, to the point that you are physically revolted and want to turn away from looking any more.

- The local co-op experience makes absolutely no sense.  The game begins and there are absolutely no goals or objectives being communicated to the players.

- Do you really need me to keep listing negatives?  This game came out was the final offering by a company exiting the console bushiness.  This game should have stayed in back in the year 2001 where it came from.

Yes I know this is a port from an old system, but if you sell a game in 2016 you get judged by 2016 standards.  This game is hideous... just STAY AWAY lol

reviewText:
The best Gamecube game ever imo. And it sucked on PC.

As this was added to Steam in 2010, I personally hoped for a version with better graphics, decent keyboard controls and a few different changes, I was let down. This is basically exactly the same as the Gamecube version, but then with some leaderboards.

Sonic Adventure 2 is by no means a bad game, but the dissapoinment makes it not worth it to buy the game on Steam. You're better off downloading an ISO and playing it on an emulator, but if you still want to give money for those hard working people over at Sonic Team, then I suggest you buy an old Gamecube and the game.

reviewText:
Charming game, but with a few problems. its very hard to get into, because of the confusing control mechanisms, but that's because it's a port. The sonic/shadow levels are brilliant, but some of the bosses are quite hard because of the confusing camera angles. the knuckles levels are utterly crap, with cheesy rap music, unclear goals and shoddy mechanics. the game is still incredibly fun, but it really needs to take a page from the original's book, and allow you to not play the knuckles levels.

6.5/10

reviewText: I absolutely loved this game on my Gamecube years back, and when I found a PC vesion, I was excited to revisit what many Sonic fans consider a masterpeice, this game is not a masterpeice.\nSo the game is split up between 3 sections, Speed (Starring Sonic and Shadow), Mech shooting (with Tails and Robotnik) and the Treasure Hunting (Knuckles and Rouge)\nWhen most people talk about how fun the game is, they are usually talking about the speed sections, and they are some of the most boring Sonic levels I have ever played.  They are all extremely linear and feel mostly the same (set aside a few level gimmicks like a truck).  These were the most fun this game offers though.  The Mech shooting is trying to cappitalize off the Gamma's playstyle in Sonic Adventure 1 and it is not nearly as fun now.  Imagine the Sonic levels, only slower, god awful controls, and has guns.  (So basically it's Shadow the Hedgehog)  The treasure hunting stages are the worst.  There is this radar" that doesn't show you were the treasure is half the time because it wants you to find them in a set order...  really?  The controls were actually decent during these
date: only this game does not work very well on a keyboard.\nThe graphics are ok enough considering how old the game is at this point

reviewText:
I cant think of a review for this brillient game so here is a recipe for a caramel cheesecake:

Gently melt the butter in a small pan over a low heat. Place the digestives in a plastic bag and crush to fine crumbs using a rolling pin; you can also do this in a food processor. Tip them into the pan with the melted butter, stir to coat, then transfer to a 20cm springform cake tin (9cm deep). Using the back of a spoon, press them into the base, making sure you seal the edges. Place in the fridge while you prepare the next stage.

If using leaf gelatine, place in a bowl, cover with cold water, soak for 5 mins, then drain. Pour 3 tbsp boiling water over the soaked gelatine and stir to dissolve. If using a sachet, see Know-how, below.

Place the crème fraîche in a small pan with the muscovado sugars and a pinch of sea salt, then gently heat, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon until the mixture liquefies and the sugar has dissolved. Give the mixture a quick whisk to get rid of any lumps. It should be warm, roughly the same temperature as the gelatine solution. Stir the gelatine and vanilla extract into the crème fraîche mixture, transfer to a bowl and cool.

Place the ricotta in a food processor and whizz until smooth, then add the crème fraîche mixture and whizz again. Pour this on top of the cheesecake base. Cover with cling film and chill overnight.
Run a knife around the sides of the tin, then undo the clip and remove it. Transfer to a plate or leave the cheesecake on the base for ease of serving. Pile the fudge flakes in the centre and dust with icing sugar. Cover and chill until required.

reviewText:
I'm going to start this review by saying this is my favorite game of all time, so I may be a bit bias.

Section 1:  Story
The story of SA2 is just a tad deeper the most sonic games, like SA1's story was.  Sonic has been mistaken for a black and red counter part called Shadow, who was released by Dr. Ivo Robotnik (Eggman), in hopes of taking over the world.  Shadow hopes to uncover his past and fufill his promise of destroying the world to Maria, as the last thing he remembers is her death.  Shadow tells Eggman that if he delivers the 7 Chaos Emeralds to the Space Colony Ark, Shadow will grant him any wish.  Eggman wants to use this to wish for world domination.  Sonic, with the help of his sidekick Tails, are there to stop Eggmans plans.  The first emerald Eggman tries to locate turns out to be the Master Emerald, which can give power to the other 7 Emeralds.  Eggman tries to take it with him, but Knuckles breaks the Master Emerald before Eggman gets away.  Now Knuckles is trying to peice together the Master Emerald while Rouge the Bat tries to steal the shards for her own greed.
I only have one problem with the story.  Knuckles and Rouge seem thrown in at the last second because SEGA felt they had to have Knuckles in, and Rouge because Knuckles needed a rival.  I'm ok with SEGA putting them in, but make them at least a LITTLE BIT relative to the story.  Rouge just ends up hanging out with Shadow and Eggman, and Knuckles only meets up with Sonic and Tails one time, then doesn't show up again untill the final mission!  They don't do ANYTHING to the story that couldn't have been done if they were both just dropped entirely.

Section 2: Atmosphere
Most of the hero stages (Knuckles, Tails, and Sonic) are preety upbeat until the near-end of the game, when they get serious for reasons that will be explained if you play the game.  The Dark stages (Shadow, Eggman, and Rouge) however, are vastly different.  Shadow's stages have the feel of knowing you are superior to everyone else, and you solve problems yourself because everyone else can't perform as well.  The Eggman stages feel as if you are evil and proud, and if anyone doesn't like it they can talk to your lasergun.  The Rouge stages have a mix of undercover, super spy and that you got this, and it's no big deal.  The art style feels a bit like the old sonic games, but mostly like a new fresh game like most other sonic games feel.  The music is the beautiful harmony that SEGA brings with nearly every sonic game, blending with the levels in a wonderful way.  I have a gripe about the amosphere too, as good as it may be.  When SEGA was making the US version of this game, they never bothered to fix the ever prominent cutscene issues.  Characters commonly cut each other off, talk simultaniously, and to top it all off, the voice sync sucks.  The problems are STILL in this version, even though they had PLENTY of opportunities to fix this.

Section 3: Gameplay
Ever played a 3D sonic game?  Well that's Sonic and Shadow's stages in a nutshell.  Fast-paced platforming action with enough tricks up it's sleeve to keep you playing.  Tails and Eggman's stages take a different approach, doing a third person shooter-like approach in mech suits.  It's O.K., but not quite as good as the Sonic and Shadow stages.  Finally we have the ever-hated Knuckles and Rouge stages.  They could have been very fun, but a few small things kept it from being perfect.  The way it works is that 3 items are scattered along the level, and you have to find them.  To aid you is your radar, which tells you if you are close to the object, and Floating TVs that give you hints.  The first problem with this mode is the camera.  In enclosed spaces, you always have to fight to see where you want to.  The second problem is the radar.  The radar only picks up the item it wants you to find.  This means that if you are near one of the items you need, but it isn't the one the radar wants you to find, you could be right next to it and never know.  The third problem is the combat.  Combat in the treasure hunting stages can be clunky and it can be very easy to miss.  Thankfully there isn't a lot of combat in these stages.  There is also a place you can unlock and go to called the Chao Island.  There you can raise Chao with fruit you find on the island, Chao Drives, and animals.  Chao Drives and animals can be found in the stages.  You can also go to a small Chao area to buy things with your rings, such as Chao Eggs, Fruit, and other things.  You can also send you Chao to school, where they will learn certian skills, name your chao, and check your chaos stats in the same area.  There is also a seperate area where you can race a gainst other chao, or if you have the Battle DLC, play karate against other chao.  Speaking of Battle, the other things you get from it are a versus mode, and a kart racing game.  The Kart racer is a bit boring, because there are no power ups besides a boost.  The other battle modes are just the story levels exept your racing in the speed stages, dueling in the mech stages, and trying to find the certian items first in the treasure hunting stages.  The chao mode can be hit or miss with players, but I adore it.  The VS mode can a great way to battle your friends, and there is always a good character for beginners.

All and all, this is a great game for beginners to the sonic franchise, a solid game for experianced players, and with the Battle DLC, a good place to battle it out with friends.  The game has a few flaws, but there's plenty to keep you playing.

Overall Score: 9/10

reviewText: Probably one of my favorite games I ever played.  This game is still great even after all these years.  One of my first gamecube games, when I saw that the sonic collection was on steam, I had to buy.  They put all the best games of sonic in the package.  This game is definately my highlight.  It is probably the best story driven Sonic game they put out yet.  It is emotional and gets you on the edge.  The gameplay only adds to the story.  Amazing gameplay and the controls are easily the most smoothest I have ever used.  There is plenty of content to do even though this game changed from a more open world the first one was to a stage by stage story with cutscenes.  I prefer the story in this game compared to the first and the soundtracks is even better.  Hope Sega can get their act together and create another Sonic game like this one.
